title: Stop attaching religion, ethnicity to criminality, Gov. Ahmed urges Nigerians
text:
Home » News » Stop attaching religion, ethnicity to criminality, Gov. Ahmed urges Nigerians Stop attaching religion, ethnicity to criminality, Gov. Ahmed urges Nigerians On 10:14 pm In News by Tony Comments 
The Kwara Governor, Dr Abdulfatah Ahmed, has called on Nigerians to desist from attaching religious and ethnic colouration to criminality, saying that such expression portends great danger to the unity of the country. 
Gov. Ahmed made the call on Tuesday while receiving the National President of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN), Rev. Samson Ayokunle, at the Government House, Ilorin. 
According to the governor, no religion preaches violence as a way of political or economic agitation, but approves constructive and peaceful engagements toward resolving perceived or real marginalisation. 
Ahmed also advised Nigerians to stop politicising serious national issues and dividing the country along religious line. 
He said that political appointments in the state were based primarily on political and geographical considerations. 
The governor urged politicians seeking appointments to do so through political structure rather than employing religious and ethnic sentiments, to avoid creating tension in the polity. 
The governor promised that his administration would to be guided by principles of transparency, equity, fairness and justice. 
He also promised to computerise land management process in the state to avoid unnecessary communal clashes and needless loss of lives and property. 
Speaking earlier, Ayokunle commended the governor for his commitment toward building sustainable peace in the state, saying that peaceful co-existence was critical to the development of any nation. 
He advised government at all levels to imbibe the principle of equity, justice and fairness ‘’to give everyone sense of belonging.’’ 
The CAN President, who is also the President of Nigeria Baptist Convention told the governor that the Baptist church had 15,000 Churches across the country with about eight million members. 
Earlier, the pastor in charge of Emmanuel Baptist Church, Sabo-Oke, Ilorin, Pastor Solomon James, said the group was in Government House to inform the governor about the 50th anniversary of the Church. 
Olawuyi also said that the church had evolved some social programmes to complement the efforts of the government in meeting its obligations to the people.
